node.title: Grids and convergence
node.bodyText:
I came across a confusing situation. I am trying to reproduce some of the particle sintering phenomena in the paper by running the following input file using combined-opt under module/combined.
When the mesh is set here, the program can compute normally and converge.
[Mesh] # Generate mesh (7/3D X 4/3D)
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 2
  nx = 70
  ny = 40
  xmin = 0
  xmax = 70.0
  ymin = 0
  ymax = 40.0
  elem_type = QUAD4
[]

But when the mesh is set this way, the program no longer converges and diverges.
[Mesh] # Generate mesh (7/3D X 4/3D)
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 2
  nx = 140
  ny = 80
  xmin = 0
  xmax = 70.0
  ymin = 0
  ymax = 40.0
  elem_type = QUAD4
[]

As you can see, I've actually done nothing but encrypt the grid, and I'm confused as to why this is happening.

can you please attach the log?
It's probably just a matter of selecting solver settings that work for the finer mesh problem

Hello, this is the log file. I saved the whole process, the calculation converges at the beginning, then diverges at about 0.15s, and then gets farther and farther on the way of divergence.
001.txt

set the max linear number of iterations higher. It calls the iteration diverged when it is slowly converging, hitting a max of 30 seemingly.
you can also consider turning off the line search with line_search = none as some iterations were failed because of that

this isnt great
    cutback_factor = 0.5
    dt = 0.001
    growth_factor = 1.1

it cuts down the time step by a lot when it fails, then grows it very slowly when passing. A failed time step every now and then can occur, but it s penalizing the time stepping a lot here

node.title: Multiple outputs per step - adaptivity
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
I used the following output Settings, but I didn't get the output for each time step. Instead, I get the output for each iteration of each time step. How should I set this up？
[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  print_linear_residuals = true
  execute_on = timestep_end
  [out]
    type = VTK # 输出 VTK 文件
    time_step_interval = 1 # 每个时间步输出
    file_base = Sintering_output # 输出文件的基础名称
    enable = true
    execute_on = 'timestep_end'
  []

hello
remove this it's not needed
    time_step_interval = 1 # 每个时间步输出

Where are the iterations coming from? From the nonlinear solver or from fixed point iterations with a MultiApp?

Thank you for your reply, specifically, my execution part is this
[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  scheme = BDF2
  solve_type = PJFNK
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -ksp_gmres_restart -sub_ksp_type
                        -sub_pc_type -pc_asm_overla'
  petsc_options_value = 'asm      31       preonly
                         ilu      2'
  l_tol = 1e-05
  nl_max_its = 30
  l_max_its = 50
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-07
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-09
  start_time = 0.0
  end_time = 1.0
  # dt = 0.00125

  [TimeStepper]
    type = IterationAdaptiveDT
    cutback_factor = 0.5
    dt = 0.001
    growth_factor = 1.1
    optimal_iterations = 15
  []
[]

i think these multiple files per time step are from steps of adaptivity.
You can try to output on timestep begin instead of timestep_end to (maybe) prevent outputting multiple files per time step

Thanks for your reply, I have modified the input file according to your suggestion, but it seems to have no effect.
[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  print_linear_residuals = true
  execute_on = timestep_end
  [out]
    type = VTK
    file_base = Sintering_output
    enable = true
    execute_on = 'timestep_begin'
  []
  # [out]
  #   type = Tecplot
  #   ascii_append = true
  # []

  [debug] # report variable residual
    type = VariableResidualNormsDebugOutput
  []
[]
@GiudGiud Hello dear developer, can you continue to give me some advice.

ok then we dont have an option to do this. You would need to modify the FEProblemSolve.C class to output at the end of the adaptivity loop, if I am correct that these files are from adaptivity. You can open them all for a time step and check that the only difference is the local mesh refinement.
Have too many output files is not really preventing you from doing anything though so I would recommend you move on
Thank you for your reply, which is a good solution to my problem

node.title: Symmteric boundary condition in 2D and 3D
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
I wanted to just simulate half of the domain in 2d and quarter in 3d thanks to the symmetry of the problem.
But I do not know how to apply symmetric boundary condition on a line in 2d and on planes in 3d.
In moose I performed simulations in RZ coordinates and specifying axis of symmetry, so I'm wondering whether symmetric boundary condition is also available in moose. Simply using no flux bc is not working in my problem.
Thanks,
Ali

Hello
This depends on the physics. For example for diffusion, symmetry is simply "no flux"
For fluid flow with finite volume, symmetry means "no flux" but also "no wall shear stress"
What physics are you solving?
Guillaume
I am simulating multiphase flow with coupled phase field (Cahn Hilliard) and Navier stokes. So my variables are vel_x, vel_y, vel_z, p, c (order parameter), w (chemical potential).

All finite element right?
I would think 0 flux would be fine for those to achieve symmetry. You may have to dive into the equations to understand why it's not

如果对称边界条件，假如对称边界垂直于x轴，则vel_x=0，
abla p  = 
abla c = 
abla w = 
abla v_y = 
abla v_z =0

node.title: Traction-free vs Stress-free boundary
node.bodyText:
I understand that when no displacement is prescribed on the boundary (i.e., free boundary conditions), the traction-free condition is defined as:
$$\sigma_{ij} \cdot n_j = 0 \quad$$,
which implies no normal or tangential traction on the boundary. However, in my simulation, I aim to implement stress-free boundary conditions, where all components of the stress tensor vanish on the boundary:
$$\sigma_{ij} = 0$$.
Could you please advise on how to achieve this in MOOSE? Are there specific settings, constraints, or additional steps required to enforce $$\sigma_{ij} = 0$$ on the boundary?
Thank you for your time and assistance.

Hello
Stress free boundary should be the default boundary condition when no BC is applied on a boundary
You should be able to verify that by exporting the stress material property on a boundary to an auxiliary variable (defined in the whole volume by default, but the auxkernel would be defined only on the boundary)
I’ve now figured it out, Thank you so much for your help!

node.title: Interpolation function in strong form Vs. weak form
node.bodyText:
Hello,
As moose solves the PDE in weak form. is it possible that the value of any additional driving force in the form of an interpolation function (like  3.eta_i.eta_j.Pz) is different when calculated in moose. If so is there any scaling rule I must follow?
Thanks.

Hello

is it possible that the value of any additional driving force in the form of an interpolation function (like 3.eta_i.eta_j.Pz) is different when calculated in moose.

I'm not sure I understand why it would be different?
You can output the contribution of a given kernel to check, using either the deprecated save_in method, or the "extra_vector_tags" options, then using a TagVectorAux to output the contribution to the residual to an auxiliary variable

//1st and 3rd term in above equation

shouldnt the 3rd term have a minus?
same for the second term?
since the first term has a + sign in both the equation and the implementation (keeping in mind you move it to the LHS so the sign in front of L disappears)

As you can see the way MOOSE implemented this equation has negative sign to the third term of equation, but if you look at the grain growth action kernel, there is no negative sign in ACInterface.

This equation is written with the term on the LHS already. So they have the sign right for the equation they wrote, but your equation has a different sign

I tried with minus sign. In that case even the normal grain growth does not work
with + sign in 3rd term

node.title: Adding a writable variable to a Kernel
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hi all,
In the computeQpResidual method in a kernel, I want to save an intermediate value to an aux variable. This won't affect the solve, it is just for post processing reasons.
I am having trouble properly writing in the aux variable in a way that it is writable.
For example
ADReal
someKernel::computeQpResidual(){

ADReal value = _grad_test[_i][_qp] * _grad_u[_qp];
_aux_var[_qp] = value

return value * (some function);

}

I want to write to _aux_var[_qp].
What is the correct way to declare this aux variable?

Hello

In the computeQpResidual method in a kernel, I want to save an intermediate value to an aux variable. This won't affect the solve, it is just for post processing reasons.

We dont typically do that. Auxvariables are computed by auxkernels.
You can use this interface to do this and save to a tagged vector
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/interfaces/TaggingInterface.html
The auxvariable is then used along with a TagVectorAux to retrieve the value that has been saved in the tagged vector
Ah I always forget about this. Thanks!

node.title: 2025 New England MOOSE & Bison Training January 15-16
node.bodyText:
The Idaho National Laboratory is providing a MOOSE and a BISON training in January 2025 at University of Massachusetts in Lowell.
For the MOOSE workshop on January 15-16:
MOOSE is an open-source finite element & finite volume framework developed by the DOE national laboratories that is the base for much of the advanced nuclear reactor modeling software. There are also several ongoing projects to develop MOOSE applications for fusion device modeling.
The Multiphysics Object Oriented Simulation Environment (MOOSE) Workshop provides an in-depth introduction to the framework. The course is two days in length and covers material starting from the mathematical underpinnings of the framework through advanced features of the MOOSE Multiapps system. The course uses a realistic multiphysics problem that is solved with increasing realism and complexity utilizing the many pluggable systems in the framework. Hands on exercises are supplied so attendees are encouraged to bring their own hardware to participate. More information about MOOSE can be found on our website.


Flow simulations of a spent fuel cask and a T-junction using MOOSE

For BISON workshop on January 17th:
The BISON fuel performance team is hosting a one-day, workshop. This workshop is intended to help prospective users get started with the code, provide an overview of the methods to model specific fuel types, and provide practical examples to help users gain experience. Please forward this message to anyone at your institution interested in BISON, fuel performance modeling, or MOOSE-related software.
WORKSHOP TOPICS
• Introduction to thermomechanical fuel performance modeling and multiphysics analysis
• Code development principles and contribution of new models
• Overview of LWR, TRISO, and Metallic fuel capabilities
• Meshing fuel geometries
• Simulation output analysis and visualization
The registration deadline will be flexible for the MOOSE training but we encourage early registration as space is limited. Registration for the BISON workshop will close January 15th. Access to a BISON license by the training date is not guaranteed. Please email me for any issue or question with registration.
Registration link: https://ncrcaims.inl.gov/Identity/Account/TrainingRegistration

node.title: Some questions about the Jacobian matrix
node.bodyText: When I was doing the calculations, it reminded me of some caveats about the Jacobian matrix, and I don't know if this is something to be concerned about. If so, how should I solve this problem?

Hello
Jacobian calculation works well for kernels and boundary conditions
but this caveat is for using a User Object to contribute to the Jacobian. This is not very standard. How are you using this feature?

The ComputeGrainForceAndTorque is the one returning this warning I think.
It should be fine to use. You should just be mindful that if you use more advanced features in the same input, the combination with this experimental feature might not work as expected

Thank you for your reply, it would be great if this warning could not be paid attention to. However, the current input file can be stable for some time, and after a while the linear solver diverges, what is the problem?

see this page for more info on troubleshooting failed sovles
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/application_usage/failed_solves.html

You seem to be missing the C++ standard headers. Did you install the rest of the dependencies using conda and if so did you remember to activate the environment?
Hi. I follow the installation instructions. i am using conda and activate the environment. I attached the output from the diagnostics.sh.

oh there is your problem

By the way, why do source files have an extension of '.c' instead of '.cpp'?

it's not .c.
It should be .C
.c is for C code. .C for C++
Thanks. It solves my problem. May I suggest to make a statement about the cpp file extention.

node.title: moose-dev=2024.12.02 installation errors misc/hit_cli.*
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
I followed the description for a clean new conda installation of moose, but got 12 errors upon ./run_tests referring to misc.hit_cli.-tests.
Is it possible, that there is a missing dependency in moose-dev=2024.12.02=mpich. I tried updating my conda env with an additional moose-pyhit, but the errors remain.
Do you have any other suggestion?
misc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists ............................................................................................................ FAILED (CODE 1)
misc/hit_cli.find/parameter_does_not_exist .................................................................................................... FAILED (CODE 1)
misc/hit_cli.find/positive_pattern ............................................................................................................ FAILED (CODE 1)
misc/hit_cli.find/negative_pattern ............................................................................................................ FAILED (CODE 1)
misc/hit_cli.find/additional_pattern .......................................................................................................... FAILED (CODE 1)
misc/hit_cli.find/additional_pattern_negative ................................................................................................. FAILED (CODE 1)
misc/hit_cli.merge ............................................................................................................................ FAILED (CODE 1)
misc/hit_cli.diff/vanilla ..................................................................................................................... FAILED (CODE 1)
misc/hit_cli.diff/color ....................................................................................................................... FAILED (CODE 1)
misc/hit_cli.diff/verbose ..................................................................................................................... FAILED (CODE 1)
misc/hit_cli.diff/verbose_color ............................................................................................................... FAILED (CODE 1)
misc/hit_cli.diff/common ...................................................................................................................... FAILED (CODE 1)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 4586 tests in 107.9 seconds. Average test time 0.5 seconds, maximum test time 83.4 seconds.
4574 passed, 106 skipped, 12 FAILED

I could upload the full verbose output of run_tests, if required, but maybe you already have an idea what might be missing? Thanks.

Hello
The full verbose output of the test failures, specifically one of these tests will help us diagnose the issue.
Guillaume
The latest standalone moose-pyhit package is also broken. This package is not necessary except for special-use cases.

Here are the details for one of these tests (sorry for posting the colors as binaries, i just wrote the outcome of run_tests to a file and copied from there):
�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0mWorking Directory: /home/moose/moose_beh/moose/test/tests/misc/hit_cli
�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0mRunning command: ./hit_wrapper.py gold/parameter_exists find Kernels/\*/variable input1.i input2.i
�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0m
�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0m################################################################################
�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0mBegin runner_run output
�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0m
�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0mRunning:  /home/moose/moose_beh/moose/framework/contrib/hit/hit find Kernels/*/variable input1.i input2.i
�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0mhit returned  127
�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0mOutput:
�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0m b'' 
�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0mdoes not match gold:
�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0m b'input1.i:9 Kernels/diff_u/variable = u\ninput1.i:13 Kernels/diff_v/variable = v\n2 matches found.\n'
�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0m3.11.8 | packaged by conda-forge | (main, Feb 16 2024, 20:53:32) [GCC 12.3.0]
�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0m/home/moose/moose_beh/moose/framework/contrib/hit/hit: error while loading shared libraries: libwaspcore.so.04: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0m
�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0m################################################################################
�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0mEnd runner_run output
�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0m
�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0m################################################################################
�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0mBegin tester output
�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0m
�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0mTester failed, reason: CODE 1
�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0m
�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0m################################################################################
�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0mEnd tester output
�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0m
misc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists �[90m...........................................................�[0m �[31mFAILED (CODE 1)�[0m

Apparently, because of the note on missing libwasp*.so libraray I came accross this post, with the important hint to
cd moose/framework/
git clean -xfdq

which finally let the tests pass successfully with the next execution of make -j$(nproc); ./run_tests -j$(nproc).
Somehow, I did remember to make clobberall, but not to git clean -xfdq. Still not sure, when and how often to use the latter (maybe you can comment on this ?!), but obviously I should remember this command, if something doesn't pass the tests.

�[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_exists: �[0m/home/moose/moose_beh/moose/framework/contrib/hit/hit: error while loading shared libraries: libwaspcore.so.04: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory

Yeah this is the error I get when using moose-pyhit (latest version).

Somehow, I did remember to make clobberall, but not to git clean -xfdq. Still not sure, when and how often to use the latter

You and me both 😆, I always stick to git commands. I trust git to clean a repo more than what we may have programmed into a Makefile. I also believe using git is quicker. My favorite two command to do so:
# cd ~/projects/moose
git clean -xfd
git submodule foreach --recursive git clean -xfd
